column1: 8;3480108210;"dougc84";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/reviews/id36241643";"2.4.6041";2;"It works
column2: but lots of room for improvement";"I'm a fan of AmbiClimate.  I've been following them since their 2.0 Kickstarter
column3: and finally picked up a unit on sale to control my home office's mini split with heat pump.

column1: Setting up the device was... troublesome.  It didn't want to connect to my wifi at first
column2: but it's been solid ever since.  Customer service with Ambi is very good - I received an email after a couple of failed attempts with suggestions and how to contact them for support.  Nice touch
column3: guys.  I also ended up having to pair a different remote with a similar numbering scheme
column7: I didn't get heat functionality at all.

column1: However
column2: since this is a review about the app: there is a tremendous amount of data and customization here - everything from graphs comparing your temperature to the outside temperature and humidity levels
column3: how long your equipment has been on and in which mode
column4: how you've tweaked the comfort setting
column7: all kinds of stuff.  It's very powerful and will provide most people - especially those with AC-only units - all the options they need.

column1: But Ambi missed the mark in quite a few places.  For starters
column2: even on my XSMax
column3: the fonts and UI elements are TINY.  Like... hard to tap on tiny.  It doesn't look good - it looks like a cheap app built by a for-hire developer for $100.  It definitely isn't
column4: but the UI misses the mark.  That chart isn't necessary on the landing page for each device either - it makes the content look even smaller and messier.  And
column5: on the charts - they are really difficult to read and understand.  A legend would be more useful than throwing two nearly-identical colors next to each other with two nearly-identical badge names in-line.

column1: Continuing with the UI
column2: the navigation buttons at the bottom conflict with the X/XS swipe bar - I'll often switch apps or go home on accident.  The sub-navigation from each button is WAY too small and I routinely hit the wrong option
column3: and some of the navigation options aren't exactly intuitive until you understand them.  One example is AC Controls vs. AI Controls (and why do I get different options for each at different times?).  Another is Deployments (which is very useful
column4: but... should be named something different

column1: However
column2: the biggest gripes I have are with features that provide a lot of complexity
column3: but have overlooked simple things.

column1: First: Away mode.  If you have an A/C-only unit
column2: away mode will probably work just fine for you.  However
column3: in the situation where you have both A/C and Heat
column4: and you live in a climate where you can have one day that has a high of 45F
column6: away mode defeats its own purpose.  You can only set a singular breakpoint for temperature.  Why can't we specify a heating and cooling point (i.e. if the temperature drops below 65
column9: turn on the A/C)?  I'm not looking forward to the spring and having to adjust this setting every day.  Nest and Ecobee have figured this out.  Let's get this working.

column1: Second: Turning off the device.  My unit is cranky: it forgets everything except for the last setting you had it on.  That includes the LED off feature
column2: which also turns off the bell/chime every time the temperature is changed.  So
column3: if AmbiClimate decides to power off the unit
column4: I'm greeted to constant beeps and chirps when the unit is turned back on until I grab the old remote
column5: hit the LED off button (which puts it into manual mode)
column7: and reenable whatever mode I was on.  It's frustrating
column8: as I continue to need my old remote
column9: which I hoped to not have to do.  It would be nice if there was a ""don't turn off"" option somewhere in the menu.  I'm smart enough that I could open up my unit and desolder the buzzer
column10: but I really don't want to do that

column1: Third: Smart Home Integration.  Yes
column2: Ambi provides an API
column3: but they have released no official smart home integrations like they said they would.  On top of that
column4: because OAuth is needed (instead of just a simple API key)
column5: writing an unofficial integration is exponentially more difficult than sending basic HTTP POST requests.  Come on
column6: Ecobee and Lifx can provide simple API keys
column9: a SmartThings integration would solve 75% of the issues I have
column10: as I could customize the behavior much more.

column1: Fourth: A dashboard widget.  Every other smart home app has one.  It wouldn't take much - just a simple temp/humidity/comfort view with maybe some buttons (hidden at first
column2: but would be shown when tapping Show More) to say if you're too cold or too hot.  This would allow things to be seen and allow some basic interaction without having to unlock your phone or open the app up at all.

column1: Fifth: With all the free space on the home page of each device
column2: I would love to see what the current settings are - temperature and mode.  I have to go to AC or AI controls to see this information
column3: which is very unintuitive.

column1: Last: Location awareness.  Sometimes I'm kicked to manual mode if I haven't left my house in a day.  I work from home
column2: in the room with the AmbiClimate
column3: and it's just annoying.  The last update said it ""fixed user getting kicked out of geolocation zone

column1: All that said
column2: it's really not a bad app - it just needs a few weeks of solid work to make it something that's a joy to use
column3: instead of working around its quirks and missing features.  Right now
column5: but not an app I really want to use if I don't have to.";"2018-11-30T22:54:32-07:00";"https://itunes.apple.com/us/review?id=980554024&type=Purple%20Software";"980554024";997;"en";"POSITIVE"

column1: I concur with other reviews that app ergonomics could stand to improve
column2: particularly that key functions have small and awkwardly placed buttons. But most people who buy a product like this aren’t going to open the app much for day-to-day usage after the first week—Siri Shortcuts
column3: Google Assistant
column4: and Alexa skills have the main voice assistant / smart speaker bases covered; for quieter moments
column5: the Today view widget handles the essentials
column6: and Siri Shortcuts or IFTTT button widgets could go the extra mile if needed. The Apple Home app and its Control Center widget become another option with the third-party AmbiBridge app running on a nearby Mac.

column1: That said
column2: since the intended primary model of usage is not to set specific temperatures but to guide and train Ambi
column3: it’s not a perfect fit for the assistants’ conception of thermostat control in their baseline smart home functionality. Custom commands may be needed in routines—macros like IFTTT applets and Shortcuts can be helpful

column1: And back to the app: what you are still going to use it for regularly is reviewing stats
column2: and that also needs work. History chart view responsiveness is sluggish (on an iPhone XS)
column3: cramped
column4: and decidedly non-native feel. The Deployments log is useful for troubleshooting but could be designed more elegantly.

column1: The app is not universal for iPad and does not rotate to landscape at all. An iPad makes a nice home automation control center
column2: and Ambi Climate is the eyesore among the apps I flip between for this purpose.

column1: Nonetheless it does what it needs to do
column2: just needs polish. I’m happy with the overall product experience.
